title: Leadership in the Law: Fireside Chat with Kevin McCarthy, General Counsel of BNY - Mayer Brown
summary: Kevin McCarthy, General Counsel of BNY, and Matthew Ingber will host this episode of Leadership in the Law, a fireside chat with Mayer Brown partner, Kevin McCarthy's latest “Leadership in the law” discussion with BNY's General Counsel, and will be introducing Kevin McCarthy as our host for this episode.
query: ("Bank of New York Mellon" OR "BNY") -gossip -celebrity -"fantasy sports" -"game recap"
full_text:
April 01, 2025
Leadership in the Law: Fireside Chat with Kevin McCarthy, General Counsel of BNY
Author:
Kevin McCarthy, General Counsel of BNY
We are delighted to share with you our latest “Leadership in the Law” discussion with Kevin McCarthy, General Counsel of BNY, and are excited to introduce Mayer Brown partner Matthew Ingber as our host for this episode. Kevin recalled several formative experiences, including one where “we made some law,” and emphasized the importance of authenticity as a personal characteristic that he has found to be key to building a successful career.

title: BNY selling building on Greenwich's Mason Street, closing private bank branch - ctpost.com
summary: The State Department of Banking put out a bulletin in March that Bank of New York's private bank facility at 10 Mason St. is closing, with a "leaseback arrangement," a four-story building at the top of Mason Street carries an appraised value of $27,474,600, a property-tax card on file at the town assessor's office, and a 2024 tax value of $19,232,220.
query: ("Bank of New York Mellon" OR "BNY") -gossip -celebrity -"fantasy sports" -"game recap"
full_text:
GREENWICH — A prominent building in central Greenwich could be gaining a new owner.
The State Department of Banking put out a bulletin in March that Bank of New York's private bank facility at 10 Mason St. is closing, though the company will maintain its wealth management office in the building, company officials said.
Advertisement
Article continues below this ad
According to a statement from management at BNY (rebranded from BNY Mellon last year), the company is "actively in negotiations" to sell the building at 10 Mason St. The wealth management operation will continue at the location, through a "leaseback arrangement."
The four-story building at the top of Mason Street carries an appraised value of $27,474,600, according to the property-tax card on file at the town assessor's office, and its assessed value in 2024 for tax purposes is $19,232,220. The structure was built in 1954, according to town records, and the owner of record is the New York City-based bank.
According to BNY, the bank has been serving the Greenwich area since 1924. The company's web site said it has a number of financial experts working in the Greenwich office, and the "team has particular expertise in multi-generational families, foundations, business owners in transition and divorce."
Advertisement
Article continues below this ad
Dozens of retail bank branches have closed around the region in recent years, and the downsizing is largely credited to the growth of online banking and financial transactions.

title: Euan Munro exits CEO role at Newton IM - PA Adviser
summary: Euan Munro, CEO at Newton Investment Management since June 2021, joined Aviva Investors and Standard Life Investments in fixed interest and multi-asset investment roles, with Mitesh Sheth becoming the sole CIO of BNY Investments' parent company, announcing his departure and congratulating former team and global client base.
query: ("Bank of New York Mellon" OR "BNY") -gossip -celebrity -"fantasy sports" -"game recap"
full_text:
Euan Munro is stepping down from his role as chief executive officer at Newton Investment Management.
In a post on LinkedIn, Munro (pictured) confirmed his departure and thanked his former team and global client base.
“It has been a pleasure to lead this storied firm. I wish you all the very best. I am leaving behind some of the best investors I have ever had the privilege to work with, they will continue to be great without me.”
See also: Gold soars, tech slumps: What happened in markets in March?
He also noted he will be “enjoying a bit of time and space” to think about his next steps.
Munro has been CEO at Newton IM since June 2021, after joining from the role of CEO at Aviva Investors, a role he filled for seven years. He has also previously worked at Standard Life Investments and Scottish Provident in fixed interest and multi-asset investment roles.
Meanwhile, Mitesh Sheth, CIO for multi-asset at Newton IM, is also leaving the firm, BNY Investments, the parent company to Newton IM, confirmed. He has been in this role for over three years, having joined from Redington where he spent almost nine years working his way up to CEO. He was recognised in the Queen’s New Year’s Honours list in Jan 2022, and awarded an MBE for leadership in diversity and inclusion across the investment industry.
A statement from the Newton said: “Over the past three years, Euan and Mitesh have made meaningful contributions to Newton’s culture and business, and we wish them well in their future endeavours.”
See also: James Rainbow joins St James’s Place Wealth Management as CEO
Both Munro’s and Sheth’s roles will not be directly replaced as the firm is moving several operations from Newton into a centralised BNY COO leadership team, as well as sales and distribution teams to existing BNY Investments’ distribution teams.
However, John Porter, previously co-CIO of Newton, will become the sole CIO of the firm, reporting to Jose Minaya, global head of BNY Investments & Wealth.
The statement added: “BNY Investments remains fully committed to the distinctive culture and philosophies of investment teams such as Newton, Walter Scott and Insight and we are confident the changes that we are announcing today will allow us to continue to deliver the high quality of service and investment outcomes.”
This story was written by our sister title, Portfolio Adviser

title: UK digital asset exchange Archax expands to US with acquisition - ledgerinsights.com
summary: Archax acquires Globacap Private Markets Inc. (Globacap PMI) a US regulated broker dealer and alternative trading system (ATS) to help institutional market participants transition from traditional to digital assets and provide regulated tools and services for institutional markets.
query: ("Bank of New York Mellon" OR "BNY") -gossip -celebrity -"fantasy sports" -"game recap"
full_text:
UK digital asset exchange Archax has acquired Globacap Private Markets Inc. (Globacap PMI) a US regulated broker dealer and alternative trading system (ATS). It bought the US company from fellow British startup Globacap which provides workflow solutions for private markets and is also active in the digital assets sector.
“The acquisition of Globacap PMI in the US builds on the strong partnership we already have with them in the UK, and is a part of that global strategy,” said Graham Rodford, CEO and co-founder of Archax.
“In particular, we want to help support institutional market participants transition from traditional to digital assets and give them the regulated tools and services they need to do that. The US is an enormous and important global market – and with the recent change of government and new, clearer and more open regulated landscape, it is important for firms in our space to have a clear US strategy – and this transaction gives us just that.”
